text: it's an exciting time to be working on
the chemistry of rare earth elements the

Scania and the lanthanides and they're
used it a lot of very important
renewable energy applications for
example hybrid electric vehicle
batteries and large-scale wind turbine
generators used for generating
electricity all use rare earth materials
China currently holds ninety-seven
percent of the world's supply of rare
earths elements in the last 8 18 months
they have been reducing their export
quotas significantly this is that a
chilling effect on the global rare
earths market that rare earths exist
everywhere including domestically one of
the problems is that rare earths occur
as composite mineral sources either in
terrestrial sources or in sea floor mud
and they have to be separated one from
another in order to be used in their
technological applications we're
studying rare earths separations and new
rare earth complexes in the context of
separations one of the ways that we're
doing that is using this electrochemical
instrumentation integrated with this dry
blocks we make new rare earth complexes
in this dry box and study their
electrochemical process electrochemical
properties in the context of rare earth
separations chemistry with results from
these studies we hope to develop a new
rare earth separations chemistry for
deployment in a domestic supply chain to
continue to contribute to renewable
energy technology I'm Eric shelter an

Jerome Robinson and we're in the

of Pennsylvania
